## The microPower power supply

TBA description

### Features:

The microPower features:

Power input:
* VUSB: 5-5.5V
* VBAT: one-cell LiIon at max 4.2V
*

Power output (Concurrent)
* Linearly regulated 3.3V, 400mA, 500mA peak
* Switching regulated 5V, 800mA
* Unregulated 3.3-5.5V (depending if battery or USB is providing power)


I/O
* USB to Serial
* I2C for sensors

Sensors (I2C)
* Battery fuel gauge
* Battery current sensing

Components used:
* [FT232RL](http://www.ftdichip.com/Products/ICs/FT232R.htm) USB to serial converter (also providing VUSB)
* [MCP73871](http://www.microchip.com/wwwproducts/Devices.aspx?dDocName=en536670) Battery charger and load balancer
* [MIC5205](http://micrel.com/index.php/en/products/power-management-ics/ldos/single-ldos/article/85-mic5219.html) 3.3V LDO Regulator
* [MAX17043](http://www.maximintegrated.com/datasheet/index.mvp/id/6546) Battery fuel gauge
* [ACS711](http://www.allegromicro.com/Products/Current-Sensor-ICs/Zero-To-Fifty-Amp-Integrated-Conductor-Sensor-ICs/ACS711.aspx) Hall-effect current sensor
* [MCP3021](http://www.microchip.com/wwwproducts/Devices.aspx?dDocName=en010539) 10-Bit A/D Converter to I2C

## Revisions & Issues

### rev 0.1

Rev 0.1 is the first published revision. This revision is missing the following items:
* Power on/off switch. An on/off switch would be a useful addition instead of adding/removing the battery.
* Power LED. It would be useful to know when the board is powered and functional.

## Files

* Altium project files (including required libraries for the headers)
* Gerber and NC Drill files
* Schematic [PDF](https://github.com/dermitza/microPower/blob/master/altium/microPower/microPower1.pdf)
